questions.text: The treatment of choice for amblyopia is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Conventional occlusion Amblyopia is the most common cause of preventable blindness in children and young adults. Most of the amblyopic visual loss is reversible if detected and treated at the appropriate time. It affects 1.0 to 5.0% of the general population.

Highyeild:

Various treatment modalities have been tried like refractive correction, patching (both full-time and part-time), penalization, and pharmacological therapy. Refractive correction alone improves visual acuity in one-third of patients with anisometropic amblyopia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - . Spectacles Disadvantages of spectacles . Image is magnified by 30%, so not useful in unilateral aphakia (produces diplopia). The problem of spherical and chromatic aberrations of thick lenses. The field of vision is limited. Prismatic effect of thick glasses. ‘Roving ring Scotoma’ (Jack in the Box phenomenon). Cosmetic blemishes especially in young aphakic. Contact lenses. Advantages of contact lenses Less magnification of Image. Elimination of aberrations and prismatic effect of thick glasses. Wider and better field of vision. Cosmetically more acceptable. Better suited for uniocular aphakia. Disadvantages of contact lenses are: more cost; cumbersome to wear, especially in old age and childhood; and Corneal complications may be associated. Intraocular lens implantation Primary intraocular lens implantation is done during cataract surgery. Secondary intraocular lens implantation Refractive corneal surgery includes: Keratophakia and Epikeratophakia Hyperopic Lasik may be tried in cases where secondary IOL cannot be implanted

questions.text: A tall thin patient with hypermobile joints and a wrist sign positive presented to the ophthalmology department on examination the following finding was present which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Marfan Syndrome The given Image shows superior temporal subluxation of the lens which is occurring in a tall thin male with hypermobile joints and positive wrist sign suggestive of Marfan syndrome People with Marfan syndrome are tall and thin with long arms, legs, fingers, and toes.

Highyeild:

Pathophysiology of Marfan Syndrome : Mutations in the fibrillin-1 gene result in the production of an abnormal fibrillin protein, leading to abnormalities in the mechanical stability and elastic properties of connective tissues.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Down syndrome is a condition in which a person has an extra chromosome. Chromosomes are small “packages” of genes in the body. They determine how a baby's body forms and functions as it grows during pregnancy and after birth. Option: C. In homocystinuria also the male presents with tall long stature but the dislocation is mostly in the inferior and nasal direction moreover the joints are rigid and not hypermobile

Extraedge:

Homocystinuria also presents with the same features but the dislocation of the lens is inferiorly and nasally.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the ophthalmology department who was tall, thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly on examination the following was found in his eye. The patient's parents gave a history of intellectual and behavioral disorders in the patient:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homocystinuria The given Image is subluxation of the lens is inferior and nasally Manifestations of homocystinuria include ectopia lentis Thromboembolic disorders and

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . features like that of Marfan syndrome But in Marfan syndrome, the dislocation of the lens is superiorly and temporally. Option: C . Edwards syndrome, also known as trisomy 18 , is a very severe genetic condition that affects how your child's body develops and grows. Children diagnosed with trisomy 18 have a low birth weight, multiple birth defects, and defining physical characteristics. Option: D. Patau's syndrome is a serious rare genetic disorder caused by having an additional copy of chromosome 13 in some or all of the body's cells. It's also called trisomy 13. Each cell normally contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, which carry the genes you inherit from your parents.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive worsening of vision in both his eyes over the past 6 months. He reports that he first noticed some blurring of his vision and glare in the evenings, which have both gotten worse in this period. He works as a tower crane operator and spends most of his day outdoors. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/100 in both eyes. A photograph of the eye is shown. Damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's current symptoms:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lens This photograph shows leukocoria ( white pupillary reflex ). Chronic UV exposure due to working outdoors is a risk factor for this condition. Gradual painless loss of vision with leukocoria in an adult suggests cataract formation. Cataracts are the most common cause of impaired vision in patients over 40 years of age.

Highyeild:

Risk factors for cataract formation include advanced age diabetes mellitus smoking heavy alcohol consumption chronic corticosteroid therapy ocular trauma, and UV exposure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Corneal edemas , which can be caused by keratitis, anterior uveitis, acute congestive glaucoma, and certain metabolic disorders (e.g., mucopolysaccharidoses), would appear as opacifications on slit-lamp examination and cause impaired visual acuity. However, such opacifications would not be restricted to the pupillary area, as is the case here. Instead, opacification would be present throughout the cornea and obscure the underlying iris. Option: B. Vitreous body pathologies, such as persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) and chronic ocular toxocariasis, can result in impaired visual acuity and leukocoria. However, PHPV typically occurs during childhood, and toxocariasis is accompanied by ocular pain. Moreover, both conditions are typically unilateral, whereas both eyes are affected in this patient. Option: D. Retinal pathologies such as retinoblastoma, retrolental fibroplasia, and Coats disease can cause leukocoria with impaired visual acuity. However, these conditions typically occur in the pediatric population, not in adults.

Extraedge:

Conditions associated with congenital and juvenile cataracts include galactosemia, chromosomal trisomie s, certain TORCH infections (e.g., rubella, toxoplasmosis), Marfan syndrome, Alport syndrome, myotonic dystrophy, and neurofibromatosis type II.

questions.text: A child has a short statute, short stubby fingers, and a brachycephaly. An eye examination is showing the following Image. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Weill Marchesani syndrome Weill Marchesani syndrome is a rare genetic disorder of connective tissue characterized by abnormalities of the lens of the eye, short stature, an unusually short, broad head (brachycephaly), and joint stiffness.

Highyeild:

Symptoms: Abnormalities of the lens of the eye Short stature Brachycephaly and joint stiffness

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Marfan syndrome affects the heart, eyes, blood vessels, and bones. People with Marfan syndrome are tall and thin with long arms , legs, fingers, and toes. Treatment includes medication to keep blood pressure low, glasses or contact lenses, and surgery. Option: C. Alport syndrome is an inherited form of kidney inflammation (nephritis). It is caused by a defect (mutation) in a gene for a protein in the connective tissue, called collagen . The disorder is rare .

Extraedge:

The ADAMTS10 gene is associated with autosomal recessive Weill Marchesani Syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to you for deviation of her R/E. Her visual acuity is 6/18 in R/E & 6/6 in L/E. On doing retinoscopy R/E is not improving with any correction. There is no abnormality with the fundus of R/E & there is no media opacity to account for the decrease in vision in R/E. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amblyopia Amblyopia is defined as partial loss of sight in one or both eyes in the absence of ophthalmoscopic or other marked objective signs. It results from psychical suppression of the retinal image . Here the girl has no objective sign of a decrease in vision in R/E still the vision is not improving with any refractive correction, therefore it is diagnosed as amblyopia.

Highyeild:

If the vision would have improved with the use of refractive correction to 6/6 then it would have been diagnosed as a refractive error.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Manifest squint - manifest squint is present when the eyes are open and being used; whereas in latent squint the eye turns only when it is covered or shut. Option: B. Refractive error - Refractive error means that the shape of your eye does not bend light correctly, resulting in a blurred image. The main types of refractive errors are myopia (nearsightedness), hyperopia (farsightedness), presbyopia (loss of near vision with age), and astigmatism. Option: D. Optic disc pallor - Optic disc pallor is the anatomic sequela of atrophy of the anterior visual pathway with the loss of retinal ganglion cell (RGC) axons projecting to the lateral geniculate body. “Optic neuropathy” refers to dysfunction of the optic nerve, and in particular, to RGCs.
